Award.AwardTitle: University of South Carolina Science and Mathematics Teacher Initiative (USC-SMTI)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) majors who would not otherwise consider a career in precollege science and mathematics teaching are entering a Master in Teaching (MT) program. Preparation of science and mathematics secondary teachers is via graduate level programs only. The MT program serves as a fifth year program open only to candidates completing the B.S. degree in a STEM discipline with an education core. Partnerships with the Midlands and Orangeburg-Calhoun Technical Colleges enhance the effort to interest freshmen and sophomore STEM majors in undertaking a course of study leading to a STEM degree with teaching certification. Lower division seminar courses for prospective teachers are offered at both the university and the two-year schools. Summer internship opportunities to work with Noyce program faculty in an established summer professional development program for mathematics and science middle school teachers and students are available to STEM majors at all the partnership institutions.

The MT program expects to be graduating up to forty one Noyce scholars over the course of the five year project. The resulting highly qualified science and mathematics teachers are committed to teach two years in a high needs school district for each of up to three years of scholarship support received. Five high needs school districts are participating in the project; these are the: Calhoun, Lexington 2, Orangeburg 5, and Richland 1 and 2 County School Districts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of South Carolina Science and Mathematics Teacher Initiative (USC-SMTI) was founded on three overarching goals: (1) recruiting, (2) preparing, and (3) retaining high quality secondary mathematics and science teachers from diverse populations prepared to teach in high need school districts. The program graduated 65 Noyce Scholars - 31 science education Scholars and 34 mathematics education Scholars. The 65 Scholars included 12 males and 53 females; fifteen scholars were from underrepresented populations.

Goal 1: Recruitment. To recruit strong teaching candidates, USC-SMTI developed a one-hour teaching practicum elective course for freshmen and sophomore STEM majors who were still undecided on a career path. The goal of the course was to introduce students to teaching by placing them in STEM classes in local high need schools to learn more about teaching as a career choice. USC-SMTI also attended career fairs and annually placed close to 3000 flyers in the hands of STEM majors promoting the USC-SMTI program as well as STEM teaching. Current and past Scholars routinely spoke about their experience in the USC-SMTI Noyce program as another effective recruitment tool.

Goal 2. Preparing. To prepare strong secondary science and mathematics teachers, USC-SMTI provided monthly support seminars for Scholars that included topics specific to high quality STEM teaching in high need schools. Scholars (both current and graduates) learned alongside one another in these seminars allowing current Scholars to learn from graduates as well as graduates to learn from current Scholars. Scholars completed nationally recognized secondary science and mathematics education programs. They received additional teaching experience in junior and senior level teaching practicum courses where they were placed in high need STEM classrooms for additional experience before becoming full time teachers. Scholars also attended both state and national professional conferences to help further develop a more global understanding of STEM education.

Goal 3. Retention. To retain strong secondary mathematics and science teachers, Scholars were assigned school-based content specific mentors to help acclimate them into teaching STEM in high needs schools. Scholars were also a part of an online support community focused on real-time challenges and questions they had as they began teaching. As noted in Goal 2, graduated Scholars were invited to attend the monthly support seminars alongside current Scholars to stay connected with the program and program faculty for additional support. Once they graduated, Scholars were also eligible to apply for small grants to help fund instructional needs specific to teaching in high needs schools.

Sixty USC-SMTI Scholars are currently still STEM teachers with some serving as mentor teachers to current students and Scholars.
